title: Guess Your Location does not return valid nearby restrooms
description: The Guess your location tool should show stuff nearby your location by distance order, currently its showing stuff on the opposite side of the country. Related PRs: https://github.com/RefugeRestrooms/refugerestrooms/pull/112 https://github.com/RefugeRestrooms/refugerestrooms/pull/110 https://github.com/RefugeRestrooms/refugerestrooms/pull/107

title: .env file variable syntax is not compatible with latest docker-compose version 1.25.5
description: ## The issue During project setup after cloning the project and installing docker, running `docker-compose` generated an error:  pierce@peridot refugerestrooms % docker-compose build ERROR: In file ./.env: environment variable name 'export DEVISE_SECRET_KEY' may not contain whitespace.  Others have run into[ similar issues](https://github.com/docker/compose/issues/6511) using `export MY_VAR=MY_VAL` in `.env` files, which are [compatible with `docker-compose` version 1.23.1 ](https://github.com/docker/compose/issues/6511#issuecomment-509873061). ## Scope / difficulty I anticipate this will be a straight-forward fix: updating the syntax of the variables as [outlined in the docker documentation](https://docs.docker.com/compose/env-file/#compose-file-and-cli-variables). ## Impact Updating `.env` will un-block setting up the project and support developers as they set up their development environment. ## Rationale I ran into this issue during project setup and I anticipate others may get blocked as well. ## Proposal Update `.env` variables so that they are compatible with the latest docker-compose version 1.25.5. ## How to actually do this: 1. Edit the `.env` file 2. Change variable declaration to be `VAR=VAL` format instead of `export VAR=VAL`. See Docker's docs on declaring default environment variables [here](https://docs.docker.com/compose/env-file/#compose-file-and-cli-variables).
text_for_topic_modeling: .env file variable syntax is not compatible with latest docker-compose version 1.25.5 ## The issue During project setup after cloning the project and installing docker, running `docker-compose` generated an error:  pierce@peridot refugerestrooms % docker-compose build ERROR: In file ./.env: environment variable name 'export DEVISE_SECRET_KEY' may not contain whitespace.  Others have run into[ similar issues](https://github.com/docker/compose/issues/6511) using `export MY_VAR=MY_VAL` in `.env` files, which are [compatible with `docker-compose` version 1.23.1 ](https://github.com/docker/compose/issues/6511#issuecomment-509873061). ## Scope / difficulty I anticipate this will be a straight-forward fix: updating the syntax of the variables as [outlined in the docker documentation](https://docs.docker.com/compose/env-file/#compose-file-and-cli-variables). ## Impact Updating `.env` will un-block setting up the project and support developers as they set up their development environment. ## Rationale I ran into this issue during project setup and I anticipate others may get blocked as well. ## Proposal Update `.env` variables so that they are compatible with the latest docker-compose version 1.25.5. ## How to actually do this: 1. Edit the `.env` file 2. Change variable declaration to be `VAR=VAL` format instead of `export VAR=VAL`. See Docker's docs on declaring default environment variables [here](https://docs.docker.com/compose/env-file/#compose-file-and-cli-variables). other-file

title: Need to get Geocoding working
description: Ultimately this is where the core of the project depends on. When data is entered it needs to be geocoded and the lat long stored in the db along with the rest of the entry. This way all the entries can be displayed on a map as well as searched via location closest to an inputted address / the user eventually on mobile.

title: Application secret keys shouldn't be kept in source control
description: There are currently two secret keys in source control, one for [Devise](https://github.com/tkwidmer/refugerestrooms/blob/46f66df3f7f8c7bfb7295477ebd4c6ab76ea4328/config/initializers/devise.rb#L7) and one for [Rails](https://github.com/tkwidmer/refugerestrooms/blob/46f66df3f7f8c7bfb7295477ebd4c6ab76ea4328/config/initializers/secret_token.rb#L12). Especially for open source websites, this is bad in that it makes many security features implemented by Rails and Devise useless.
text_for_topic_modeling: Application secret keys shouldn't be kept in source control There are currently two secret keys in source control, one for [Devise](https://github.com/tkwidmer/refugerestrooms/blob/46f66df3f7f8c7bfb7295477ebd4c6ab76ea4328/config/initializers/devise.rb#L7) and one for [Rails](https://github.com/tkwidmer/refugerestrooms/blob/46f66df3f7f8c7bfb7295477ebd4c6ab76ea4328/config/initializers/secret_token.rb#L12). Especially for open source websites, this is bad in that it makes many security features implemented by Rails and Devise useless. source-file source-file source-file source-file

title: Guidelines for setting up dev environment could be clearer.
description: I think that it would be useful to add a bit more clarification on setting up vagrant -- I ssh'ed into vagrant, and then tried to copy and paste the commands below, only to realize that `rake vagrant:shell['rails s -b 0.0.0.0']` was within the shell. I would suggest that we specify that if someone was going to develop while logged into vagrant, they just use the command `rails s -b 0.0.0.0` if the have ssh'ed in, otherwise, use this command: `rake vagrant:shell['rails s -b 0.0.0.0']`
